Message.Title: Obama DOJ loses in court
Message.Msg: A federal court in Washington, DC, held last week that political appointees appointed by President Obama did interfere with the Department of Justice’s prosecution of the New Black Panther Party. Topic.Title: YhOO's value just went up-Alibaba close to 8 BILLION

Message.Msg: This is important news, but nobody pay attention to it. They only care about buyout. Wake up day dreamer.

Message.Title: Alibaba reportedly close to raising $8B, NY Times reports
Message.Msg: Alibaba Group is reportedly closing in on its goal of raising more than $8B in financing, which it intends to use to buy back a 20% stake in itself from Yahoo (YHOO), according to the New York Times. Yahoo will receive $6.3bn in cash and up to $800m in newly issued Alibaba preferred stock, the companies said in a statement on Sunday night. To finance the deal Alibaba will raise a mix of debt and equity capital. If the new fundraising gives Alibaba a higher value, Yahoo’s payout will be increased. Yahoo will also receive a one-time payment of $550m to settle Alibaba’s use of the Yahoo China name. The deal paves the way for an eventual initial public offering of Alibaba. Yahoo will sell a further 10 per cent stake in the Chinese company as part of any listing, a date for which has not yet been determined. Yahoo will retain its final 10 per cent stake, to be sold at market prices after the IPO following a customary lock-up period.

Topic.Title: Alibaba reportedly close to raising $8B, NY Times reports

Message.Msg: Yahoo intends to return "substantially all" of the cash proceeds, after taxes, to shareholders. While the form of the returned capital hasn't been finalized, Yahoo has increased its share buyback authorization by $5 billion with the agreement. In addition, Alibaba will make an upfront royalty payment of $550 million and continuing royalty payments for as many as four years.

Topic.Title: Alibaba reportedly close to raising $8B, NY Times reports

Message.Msg: The agreement includes substantial financial incentives for Alibaba to raise the additional equity at a valuation higher than US$35 billion. At the minimum price and assuming the initial repurchase of the full 20% stake, Yahoo! would receive from Alibaba consideration of approximately US$7.1 billion, composed of at least US$6.3 billion in cash proceeds and up to US$800 million in newly-issued Alibaba preferred stock.

Topic.Title: Alibaba reportedly close to raising $8B, NY Times reports

Message.Msg: Alibaba Group must pay a higher price to Yahoo! if it raises $500M or more replacement equity within a designated period of time post close (generally the earlier of nine months post closing or April 30, 2013)

Message.Title: anyone else get this message???
Message.Msg: Anyone else get this on their Yahoo e-mail account? "Yahoo! Mail is now even faster, safer, and easier to use. Yahoo! now automatically identifies items such as words, links, people, and subjects from your email to learn what matters to you so that we can deliver exciting new product features and relevant ads. Before you can access Yahoo! Mail, we need your consent to our new Terms of Service and the Yahoo! Mail Privacy Policy. Learn more about how we protect your privacy." The problem is, the "Terms of Service", "Privacy Policy" and "Learn More" links......DON'T WORK !!! I am required to either click the "I Accept" button. (self explanatory), OR the "No Thanks" button, which I assume means I wave my rights. So they are going to read my e-mails so they can sell that info to advertizers!.... And, who knows what else! Where's the privacy??? Sorry, switching to Hot-Mail!
Doesn't Yahoo test before they install changes? It seems Yahoo has a habit of putting in changes without enough testing. Somebody should be FIRED!

Message.Title: Advice for Yahoo's new CEO
Message.Msg: Here's a suggestion for Yahoo's new absurdly-overpaid CEO, assuming that her mission is to rebuild Yahoo's faded image: the next time Yahoo employees muck-up the entire Mail service (which always seems to happen during regular business hours when access to reliable mail is critical for my business), maybe use your Home Page to post a little announcement to indicate that Yahoo is aware of the problem, is working on it, and expects to have the problem corrected by X time. That's not so difficult, is it? I am getting pretty near the end of my rope with Yahoo's constant reliability issues.
